nodes.title: General site characteristics
nodes.body:
Yidtsé KharYid rtse mkhar is located on an eponymous mountain a little below its summit. At the southeast base of the sacred Yidtsé KharYid rtse mkhar mountain there is a high volume spring, the source of the Kongchen ChuKong chen chu. Yidtsé KharYid rtse mkhar mountain occupies a salient position near the confluence of several valleys and basins. The remains of three cubic tombs are found on a relatively level stretch of ground, which is hemmed in by three large crags. These tombs are perched 230 m above the KongchenKong chen valley and occupy elevated rocky ground. From the site there are long views in all directions except in the north, the direction of the Yidtsé KharYid rtse mkhar summit (5030 m). The terrain is sandy and thickly covered in rocks. The cubic tombs are constructed of a blue-gray grained metamorphic (?) rock of variable length (up to 60 cm long), which has weathered to a reddish color. Some of the stones of the central chambers have orange climax lichen growing on them. Although the tombs are in poor condition, they do not appear to have been disturbed for a long time.

As with virtually all the cubic tombs sites, those of Yidtsé KharYid rtse mkhar were probably desecrated when Buddhism became the banner of the dominant political forces of the region. This destruction of tombs was probably part of the process of subjugation and the severing of the old sociopolitical links of which they were apart. The mountaintop cubic tombs, by virtue of their prominent and lofty positions, were conspicuous symbols of the archaic cultural order.

nodes.title: Oral tradition
nodes.body: According to local drok pa’brog pa, Yidtsé KharYid rtse mkhar is an ancient MönMon monument.

nodes.title: Site elements
nodes.body: The outer shells of the three cubic tombs have largely disintegrated. Only tiny coherent wall fragments are extant. None of the tombs appears to have been well aligned in the cardinal directions. The central chambers (reliquaries) of the tombs were carefully constructed.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS1
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS1 (2 m x 2.7 m x 1 [maximum height]) has a partially intact central chamber, which measures 45 cm x 35 cm x 40 cm (depth).

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS2
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS2 (2.1 m x 2.3 m x 70 cm) is located 15 m east of FS1 at the same elevation. The base of the central chamber is intact (50 cm x 80 cm x 35 cm [maximum depth]).

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS3
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS3 (2 m x 1.5 m x 60 cm) is 4.5 m south of and 1.5 m lower than FS2. The fragmentary base of the central chamber is approximately the same size as that in FS2.
